title: Through the keyhole in hotels around the world that have incredible hidden features

If you like surprises, then these are the hotels for you.
They are the inns, B&Bs and hotels around the world where all is not as it seems, with everything from hidden rooms behind bookcases and secret beaches to secret military bunkers and even an invisible 54th floor.
For instance, in Warwickshire, guests at a country manor are given an extra treat when entering their room - because the bathroom is concealed behind a working bookcase.
At one Maldives resort, a secret beach only comes to light during certain times of the day and off the coast of England, guests can hole up in a hotel that is hidden in a 19th-century Victorian sea fort.
Read on to discover the best hidden hotel features around the world, for the traveller who likes the element of surprise on their holiday...
Underground railway - The Waldorf Astoria, New York City
'Track 61' platform is hidden under The Waldorf Astoria in New York
Hidden underneath the opulent Waldorf Astoria hotel, the secluded 'Track 61' platform was one of many ways President Franklin D Roosevelt, stricken by polio and paralyzed from the waist down since 1921, would hide his affliction.
When visiting New York City, often from his childhood home in Hyde Park, upstate New York, the siding would allow him to make it to the Waldorf's Presidential suite without attracting public attention.

His private railway car - at that point still the luxury travel option of choice - was able to pull inside the station, at which point his limousine could drive straight off the carriage into an elevator connected directly to the hotel.
According to Sam Roberts, the author of a book on Grand Central, whenever a President stays in the Waldorf, a fully-manned diesel train also waits underneath in case he needs to escape an attack.
No Man's Land Fort, the Solent, England
No Man's Land Fort is a Victorian sea fort in the middle of the Solent that houses a luxury hotel
If you ever wanted to push the boat out (literally) and stay at one of the most unusual hotels on the ocean, look no further than No Man's Land Fort, a Victorian sea fort in the middle of the Solent.
The spectacular isolated fort, one of three guarding the entrance to the Solent, just off the coast of the Isle of Wight, has been turned into a luxury impregnable haven complete with a rooftop hot tub, shops and even its own nightclub, thanks to a multi-million pound revamp.
From the outside, it is impossible to tell there is anything inside the bleak building - the unique hotel looks like it could be a fortress of a James Bond villain and can sleep 44 guests with a capacity of 200 for parties and events.
Secret passageway - Penthouse suite at The Fairmont hotel in San Francisco
The penthouse at the Fairmont hotel in San Francisco has a secret passageway that leads to the hotel roof
The Fairmont hotel in San Francisco's 6,000 square foot Penthouse costs $15,000 (£9,700) per night and is one of the swankiest hotel rooms in the city.
Understandably for that price, many of the guests booking the room, which in the past featured the likes of Mick Jagger and Prince Charles, have a high profile that means they prefer to avoid busy public spaces.
Inside the suite's library is a secret passage that leads to the roof and in the past, important politicians used it to get to the helipad away from prying eyes.
Secret bunker - Greenbrier Hotel in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia
Greenbrier Hotel in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, hides a secret government bunker underneath
Under the luxurious Greenbrier Hotel in White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, is a secret bunker protected by 3-foot-thick concrete walls and an air-intake system designed to filter out dangerous radioactive fall-out.
Secretly constructed under the hotel five hours away from the capital by order of President Eisenhower from 1958 to 1962, the bunker was codenamed 'Project Greek Island' and was built as scions of America's political classes such as the Kennedy's and even the Duke and Duchess of Windsor vacationed above.
Finally complete in 1962, the bunker was the size of a Walmart store and boasted rations for 30 years and 1,100 beds, assigned individually to a serving member of the United States government.
It has a dormitory to sleep 1,000 people, a kitchen and hospital stocked up with 30 years of supplies
There are also two smaller - one seating about 470 people, which was big enough to host the 435-member House of Representatives, while the smaller hall had a seating capacity of about 130, suitable as a temporary Senate chamber.
In addition to the huge bunker that had a a broadcast center, a dormitory to sleep 1,000 people, a kitchen and hospital stocked up with 30 years of supplies, there was also a huge 7,000-foot landing strip.
Hidden free beer tap - The Crab Manor Hotel in North Yorkshire
The Crab Manor hotel has a hidden free beer tap somewhere on the premises
The Crab Manor hotel aims to take guests to some of the best hotels in the world without needing to leave North Yorkshire.
This means that guests choose from a range of rooms in an 18th Century Georgian Manor, a tranquil thatched lodge and Scandinavian pine cabins among other themes.
But one of the favourites among guests is the hidden free beer tap, which is located somewhere in the hotel.
Guests can reward themselves with a cool pint of lager on its discovery.
Secret drawing room - The Wellington Hotel, Madrid
The Wellington Hotel in Madrid has a secret drawing room hidden behind a bookcase in the library
The Wellington Hotel's location in the Salamanca neighborhood of Madrid and their Michelin star-rated Kabuki Wellington restaurant make it extremely popular among foreign guests and locals.
But the hotel has thought of an innovative solution for those hoping to find a quiet place to relax away from their bedroom.
Behind a secret door in the library sits a large drawing room where guests can enjoy table service drinks and find a quiet spot to read the newspaper.
Strange concrete bunker on the fifth floor - Yanggakdo hotel in Pyongyang, North Korea
The Yanggakdo hotel in Pyongyang has a secret fifth floor that doesn't feature on the lift buttons
North Korea has more secrets than almost any country in the world, so it should come as little surprise that one of the capital's main hotels features on this list.
The Yanggakdo hotel in Pyongyang is the country's largest hotel and it is also the second tallest building in the country.
But guests taking the lift to their rooms were surprised to note that there was no fifth floor listed on the elevator buttons.
Previous guests who took the stairs to the fifth floor found a strange concrete bunker with every wall covered in state propaganda and several locked doors.
Hidden bathroom - Coombe Abbey Hotel in Warw ickshi re
A bedroom in Coombe Abbey Hotel has a bathroom hidden behind a bookcase (far right)
Coombe Abbey Hotel in Warwickshire is a quintessential English country retreat.
The four star country house, which is set in 500 acres of parkland, was originally built as a Cistercian Abbey in the 12th Century.
It has since been remodelled as an upmarket hotel with 119 rooms, but still retains some of the mystery of the abbey.
One of these hidden mysteries is in one of the bedrooms, where guests have to search for their bathroom, eventually discovering it behind a moving bookcase.
Secret retreat - UXUA Casa Hotel & Spa in Trancoso, Bahia, Brazil
UXUA Casa Hotel & Spa offers a 'secret casa' to returning guests for special occasions
Every guests want to feel special... and what better way to achieve that than to offer them something which isn't available to others?
At UXUA Casa Hotel & Spa, an eco-luxe retreat located in the remote Bahian fishing village of Trancoso, returning guests are given the option of a 'secret casa'.
The ‘secret casa’ called Casa Dona Frozina is not listed on the hotel’s website and is only available to previous guests for special bookings.
Hidden behind the retreat's 'town square', the casa features a private garden, weathered wooden pillars, antique furnishings, an indoor/outdoor bathroom with a sunken bathtub, sofas covered in vintage African indigo linen and hammocks on the patio.
Hidden beach - Kuramathi Island Resorts, the Maldives
Kuramathi Island Resorts in the Maldives has a hidden beach that only appears in low tide
The Maldives is the king pin of exotic beach holidays and they triumph once again with their hidden gem.
Kuramathi Island Resorts in the Maldives has a hidden beach which only appears during low tide.
The snaking one-kilometre-long pure white sand bank comes and goes with the tide and staff at the resort lay out beach furniture for guests on its arrival.
